eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading and overheating.
description: This extension allows objects to fire bullets. To use it, add the behavior to the object that will shoot, then use the provided action to launch another object as the bullet.
The properties of the behavior can be used to customize:
- Firing multiple bullets at a time ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fire-bullet))
The speed can be specified when using the actions to fire the bullets.
The bullets are automatically given a permanent force to make them move (no need to use a linear movement or move them with another behavior).
A simple example shows how to make firing patterns ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://firing-patterns)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating. Once added to your object that must shoot, use the behavior action in your events to fire another object as a bullet. This action will also make the bullet move (using a permanent force) at the speed specified in the action.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: FireBullet

events.comment: Creators can use the "FireBullet" action multiple times in a frame and it will be counted as a single "shot".

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Arthur Pacaud (arthuro555)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ArrayTools
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A collection of utilities and tools for working with arrays.
description: - Combining arrays (concatenate into new array, append all children to another array)
- Finding a value in an array (find index expression, contains condition)
- Get a portion of an array (slice)
- Add and remove lots of children at specific indices at once (fill, splice, shift, pop, add at index)
- Randomness (shuffle children, get a random child)
- Mathematical operations using arrays (sum of all numbers, biggest/smallest number, average number, median number)
- String inter-operation (split string into array, join array array children to string)

inlineCode: // Cast to array to ensure getAllChildrenArray returns the real array
// At the position of the array (i), remove 1 element (the array),

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @Bouh, D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ExtendedVariables
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add conditions, actions and expressions to check for the existence of a variable, copy variables, delete existing ones from memory, and create dynamic variables.
description: - Conditions to check if a global/scene/object variable exists.
- Actions to copy object variables, global and scene variables.
- Actions to delete an existing global/scene variable from memory.
- Actions to create a global/scene variable using a text expression, rather than a variable name input.
- Expressions to get the value or text from a global/scene variable using a text expression, rather than a variable name.
Text expressions allows to enter the name of the variable with an expression like `"MyVar"+ ToString(Variable(Health))`

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (tristan@victrisgames.com)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.fullName: Make object travel to random positions
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: TravelToRandomPositions
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make object travel to random positions (with the pathfinding behavior).
description: When the action is used, the object(s) will select a random nearby 2D location and begin moving towards it (using the 2D Pathfinding behavior).

If desired, choose a direction and how closely you want the object to follow it.  This can be used to make objects chase (or run away from) the player, or to make objects cross the screen using a meandering path.
If you keep using the action, once the object reaches a destination, it will select a new random location and begin moving towards it.
If you want to modify the speed of the object, edit the Pathfinding behavior of the object.

eventsFunctions.description: Make object travel to a random position around the object current position. The movement is initiated only when the object is not moving already (its Pathfinding behavior speed is 0).  Move towards a specified angle, if desired.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Make object travel to a random position, with optional direction
eventsFunctions.name: TravelToRandomPositions
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move _PARAM1_ to random positions, where each stop is at least _PARAM3_px and at most _PARAM4_px from the current position. Move towards angle _PARAM5_ with a bias of _PARAM6_

events.comment: Create a new destination every time the object stops
Use default values if needed

parameters.description: Object that will be travelling (must have Pathfinding behavior)
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Direction (in degrees) the object will move towards (Range: 0-360)
parameters.name: Direction

parameters.longDescription: For example: "0" picks a completely random direction, "0.5" will select a direction within the half-circle that faces the specified direction, and "1" simply uses the specified direction.
parameters.name: DirectionBias

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)

This works with any kind of movement (forces, physics, dragging, etc) because it tracks the object position to compute the direction of movement.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ObjectSlicer
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Slice an object into smaller pieces that match the color of original object.
description: Useful for creating death animations such as explosions, crumbling, dissolve, or teleportation effects.
Object used for pieces should be a solid white color (otherwise the color will not match the original object color).
- Adjust the collision mask to control where pieces will be created,
- Pieces are linked to the original object which can be used in other events (i.e. explode away from the original object)
This example shows how to slice objects: [open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://object-slicer.json).

eventsFunctions.description: Slice an object into smaller pieces that match color of the original object. The new object should be a solid white color.
eventsFunctions.name: SliceObjectIntoPieces
eventsFunctions.sentence: Cut _PARAM1_ into _PARAM3_ vertical strips and _PARAM4_ horizontal strips using _PARAM2_ for the new objects. Delete original object: _PARAM5_

events.comment: Calculate dimensions of small objects
Record the top left corner of sprite
Scan sprite from top to bottom
Search left to right
Record the center of Fragment (used to check if it would be inside the collision mask)
Only create objects when their center would be inside the collison mask of the object
Adjust the size of the new object
Set position based on center of piece (in case the origin has been moved)
Match the color of the pixel that is in the center of the new Fragment
Search to the right
Search down and start over on the left side
Delete object if desired

parameters.longDescription: Recommended: Use a sprite that is a single white pixel
parameters.name: WhitePiece

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Bounce the object off another object it just touched.
description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched.
>  This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
The Breakout-like example uses this extension to make balls bounce ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://breakout)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctions.description: the number of times this object has bounced off another object.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceCount

propertyDescriptors.label: Bounce count
propertyDescriptors.description: Number of times this object has bounced off another object
propertyDescriptors.name: BounceCount
